In addition to the PPE upgrade the outside pipe line heating system will be equiped with a visual indicator to show that it it is operating.  The Chemical Unloader's operational instructions are being updated to handle the PPE requirements, inspection of TDI closure devices to ensure that they are tool tight, and to ensure that the heat tracing is functioning.

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY                                                                                                                          There have not been any spills of TDI in the past five-years.                                                                                                    THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM                                                                                                                    Our Emergency Response team receives annual 8 hour refresher Hazwoper training, American Red Cross First Aid training, and DOT annual refresher training.  The team has a spill drill with a realistic problem annually.  The drill is critiqued and the members of the team work on a correction plan to improve equipment and procedures.  The team will periodically have table top drills or dress out drills during the year.                                                                                                                                        The Incident Command Team has an organizational structure that have jobs assigned with alternates, but the HazMat team is trained to do all the related duties in case they are short personnel.  The Incident Commander has people to control the entry, data collect, notify agencies, energency services, supplies, finances, etc.                                                                                                                                                                                Our entry team would only handles minor releases, where they can control and stop the release. It is Carpenter Co.'s intention is to maintain a safe and healthful working environment for all its employees.  In order to meet Carpenter Co.'s goals all management and hourly employees are held responsible for our Safety and Health Program.  To empower our people communicating policies and procedures along with training are two important elements of our program.  Auditing, investigating incidents and taking corrective measures to prevent future mishaps are the tools used to maintain our programs.  Our Chairman of the Board and CEO has set the standard for Carpenter Co. in the corporate safety and health policy which he signed.                                                                                                                                                            THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES                                                      To control accidental releases our company has a PM system in place to check all equipment that could cause a release or other problems.  These PMs are monitored annually by our corporate Engineering Department.  In addition to the monitoring of the PM's, Corporate annually have the Health, Safety and Environmental departments conduct audits.  These audits are in addition to departmental monthly audits.                                                                                                                            Prior to start-up a pre-start check of equipment is conducted by the employees and during a pour the computer system monitors chemical flow and if a flow problem is detected the system shuts down.  In addition to the hardware monitoring the pouring team monitors the process closely and if a problem arises then they can take the appropriate action to prevent a release.  When a railcar or tanker is being unloaded it is being monitored by the Chemical Unloader and Pouring Clerk via TV the computerized pumping system monitors valve openings and the storage

tank levels.                                                                              Ninety percent of the work force in the department are a part of our HazMat team.  This team recieves annual eight hour refresher training, first aid training and DOT training.  The team conducts an annual drills with realistic problems.  The drills are critiqued and the necessary adjustment are made to improve the team's skill level.  In addition to the full blown drills, minor drills are conducted in the form of table top drills and dress out drills.                                                                                                    It is the policy of Carpenter Co. - Tupelo Division in the case of a spill to first evacuate the department and secure the perimeter than plan the task and assign duties.  Our HazMat team will only control and stop the release if it is minor.  When the conditions exceed our capabilities we call the Tupelo Fire Department - HazMat Unit and if necessary an approved outside environmental emergency response contractor will be call to clean up.  The HazMat team has people assigned to make the necessary calls to the proper agencies for reporting reasons, emergency response, supplies, financing, etc.,. These jobs would be conduct as directed by the Incident commander.                                                                                                    HANDLING OF REGULATTED SUBSTANCE                                                                                                                    The primary activity at Carpenter Co. - Tupelo Division is the manufacturing of polyurethane foam for the furniture industry.  The main ingredient of foam is TDI, which is regulated and requires us to have a risk management plan (RMP) in place.  This facility can have around 2,000,000 lbs of TDI on site at one time.                                                                                            GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE P

REVENTION PROGRAM                                                                                            In the event of an accidental release of our TDI we are required under the Clean Air Act 40 CFR 68 to have a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in place to first prevent a relase through training, assessing hazards, correcting potential hazards through PMs and by improving our process.  In addition to the RMP we have developed an Integrated Contingency Plan, which handles fire, chemcial spills, threats against the company or employees, severe weather, personal injury emergencies to comply with:  Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA), the Superfund Amendment and Reauthorization Act (SARA), the Risk Management Program regulations, the Clean Water Act (CWA), the Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) requirements, Spill Prevention Countermeasures and Control (SPCC) regulations, the Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (Hazwoper) standard, the OSHA Emergency Action Plan standard, and the Mississippi Comprehensive Waste Minimization Program (CWMP).                                                                                                                                                                           In addition to our emergency response systems there are physical barriers to contain the TDI and maintain the substance on site where it can be neutralized and removed.  If all else fails our employees are trained to handle releases safety and to involve the community agencies to protect the general population.
